title: What's the difference between plastic clarinet reeds and wood clarinet reeds? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m slightly surprised that no-one has mentioned the obvious fact that a wooden reed absorbs moisture and this causes it to swell slightly and increase in mass, which has a dampening effects on some harmonics and higher frequencies. It “warms” the sound. A synthetic reed doesn’t absorb moisture (although it might coat the surface and get blown off in tiny drops) and this causes it to vibrate very differently because there’s a completely different and far less even damping effect. The physics of materials is very important! Organics behave very differently - less consistently, but with more chance of finding an ideal that suits an individual’s style and preference… variety is good, in musical terms.

Plastic reeds are notorious for playing out of tune. They do not produce a “characteristic tone”. They produce a tone, but not the one professionals recognize as the right sound. They are fine for amateurs or someone who does not play with other wind instruments. I use them for demonstrating instruments to my students, but I only do so once a year. Wooden reeds are too expensive to only use once. Wayne mentioned not needing to sand or balance, but I have never found a plastic reed out of the box that didn’t need to be adjusted. Even many wooden reeds still need adjusting.
